title: Ticket #4453: Improve scalability of CCB
description:
There are three somewhat-wacky things we do in the CCB that could be improved:

  1. CCB has a timer which, when fires, calls select() individually on every socket for every target. 10,000 targets connected? That's 10,000 invocations of select(). DanB left a message saying that, because CCB has so many targets registered, we keep things out of DC. Instead, we can register a single epoll FD with DC and add all the targets to the epoll watch for an O(1) operation.

  2. CCB blocks on reading off the initial CEDAR message. This is similar to what we've hit before - if we change readReady for ReliSocks to reflect whether there is a CEDAR message to read instead of bytes on the sock, then we should only invoke the registered callback when a complete message has arrived. This should greatly decrease the chance we block on the network in the CCB.

  3. When we read from a socket, we typically call select() with one file descriptor in order to have the desired timeout behavior. The runtime of select is a function of the largest passed file descriptor number. If we switch to poll for this situation (relatively unobtrusive change), the runtime is O(1).

Branch posted: https://github.com/bbockelm/htcondor/tree/ccb_epoll
remarks:
2014-Jul-24 11:05:25 by bbockelm:
Review was done on the phone with Jaime. Merged this.

2014-Jul-29 14:24:20 by jfrey:
Code Review

* The two variants of Selector::set_timeout() now behave differently with respect to using poll() and a timeout with sub-second granularity. They should behave the same.

* Why the addition of USE_POLL in the Selector files? I'd prefer a more specific name for a macro defined in selector.h, like SELECTOR_USE_POLL. I don't like defining dummy poll macros and structs in the Selector header file. I'd prefer that to be confined to selector.cpp and not affect other source files that include selector.h.

* I don't like the trickery of the epoll fd masquerading as a pipe to daemon-core. But I also don't want to add an array for yet another type of handler in daemon-core just for this one use.

* This is in the existing code, but I hate that for the object named BlockingModeGuard, a value of true means non-blocking. That's backwards. The meaning should be reversed or there should be an enum or typedef that provides more explicit names (like BlockingMode and NonBlockingMode).

2014-Jul-29 15:09:44 by jfrey:
Code Review (cont.)

Coverity found another issue:

* In Selector::execute(), if a timeout hasn't been set, then the poll() call will dereference a NULL pointer when computing the timeout value. The fix is to pass a negative value to poll() when tp is NULL.

2014-Aug-01 09:44:43 by bbockelm:
Ok, review items are fixed and things check out in batlab. Closing ticket; Jaime, feel free to reopen if there's something I missed.

2014-Aug-04 11:07:33 by jfrey:
Code Review

Your changes look good.
